com.ikalagaming.event

Class EventQueue

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ikalagaming.event.EventQueue
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<Event>, java.util.Collection<Event>, java.util.Queue<Event>

    public class EventQueue
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Queue<Event>
    The queue that events are placed in pending dispatch.
    Author:
    Ches Burks

      • addAll

        public boolean addAll(java.util.Collection<? extends Event> events)
        Adds all of the events in the given Collection to the end of the queue. Elements are added in the order they appear in the supplied collection.
        Specified by:
        addAll in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Parameters:
        events - A list of events to add to the queue.
        Returns:
        true on success, false in the event of a failure

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all of the elements from this collection (optional operation). The collection will be empty after this method returns. This does not actually clear out the data, only resets the head and tail positions.
        Specified by:
        clear in interface java.util.Collection<Event>

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.lang.Object object)
        Returns true if the queue contains the specified element and it has not already been dispatched. More formally, returns true if and only if this queue contains at least one element e such that (o==null ? e==null : o.equals(e)).
        Specified by:

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Returns true if there are no more events left to be processed. Note that this will return true if there is data stored in the queue which has already been fetched and is not going to be used again, even though the data structure is not actually empty.
        Specified by:
        isEmpty in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Returns:
        false if there are unprocessed events, true otherwise

More formally, removes an element e such that (o==null ? e==null : o.equals(e)), if this collection contains one or more such elements. Returns true if this collection contained the specified element (or equivalently, if this collection changed as a result of the call).
        Specified by:

      • removeAll

        public boolean removeAll(java.util.Collection<?> events)
        Removes all of this collection's elements that are also contained in the specified collection (optional operation). After this call returns, this collection will contain no elements in common with the specified collection.
        Specified by:
        removeAll in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • retainAll

        public boolean retainAll(java.util.Collection<?> events)
        Retains only the elements in this collection that are contained in the specified collection (optional operation). In other words, removes everything in the queue that is not in the supplied collection.
        Specified by:
        retainAll in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • toArray

        public <T> T[] toArray(T[] newArray)
        Returns an array containing all of the valid events in the queue. the runtime type of the returned array is that of the specified array. If the collection fits in the specified array, it is returned therein. Otherwise, a new array is allocated with the runtime type of the specified array and the size of this collection.

        If this collection fits in the specified array with room to spare (i.e., the array has more elements than this collection), the element in the array immediately following the end of the collection is set to null. (This is useful in determining the length of this collection only if the caller knows that this collection does not contain any null elements.)

        If this collection makes any guarantees as to what order its elements are returned by its iterator, this method must return the elements in the same order.

        Like the toArray() method, this method acts as bridge between array-based and collection-based APIs. Further, this method allows precise control over the runtime type of the output array, and may, under certain circumstances, be used to save allocation costs.

        Suppose x is a collection known to contain only strings. The following code can be used to dump the collection into a newly allocated array of String: 

             String[] y = x.toArray(new String[0]);
        Note that toArray(new Object[0]) is identical in function to toArray().
        Specified by:
        toArray in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Type Parameters:
        T - the runtime type of the array to contain the collection
        Parameters:
        newArray - the array into which the elements of this collection are to be stored, if it is big enough; otherwise, a new array of the same runtime type is allocated for this purpose.
        Returns:
        an array containing all of the elements in this collection
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayStoreException - if the runtime type of the specified array is not a supertype of the runtime type of every element in this collection
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified array is null

      • add

        public boolean add(Event event)
            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException,
                   java.lang.NullPointerException
        Inserts the specified element into this queue if it is possible to do so immediately without violating capacity restrictions, returning true upon success and throwing an IllegalStateException if no space is currently available.
        Specified by:
        add in interface java.util.Collection<Event>
        Specified by:
        add in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Parameters:
        event - the element to add
        Returns:
        true if this collection changed as a result of the call
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the element cannot be added at this time due to capacity restrictions
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified element is null

      • element

        public Event element()
              throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
        Retrieves, but does not remove, the head of this queue. This method differs from peek() only in that it throws an exception if this queue is empty.
        Specified by:
        element in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Returns:
        the head of this queue
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if this queue is empty

      • offer

        public boolean offer(Event event)
              throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Inserts the specified element into this queue if it is possible to do so immediately without violating capacity restrictions. When using a capacity-restricted queue, this method is generally preferable to add(com.ikalagaming.event.Event), which can fail to insert an element only by throwing an exception.
        Specified by:
        offer in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Parameters:
        event - the element to add
        Returns:
        true if the element was added to this queue, else false
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified element is null

      • peek

        public Event peek()
        Retrieves, but does not remove, the head of this queue, or returns null if this queue is empty.
        Specified by:
        peek in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Returns:
        the head of this queue, or null if this queue is empty

      • poll

        public Event poll()
        Retrieves and removes the head of this queue, or returns null if this queue is empty.
        Specified by:
        poll in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Returns:
        the head of this queue, or null if this queue is empty

      • remove

        public Event remove()
             throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
        Retrieves and removes the head of this queue. This method differs from poll() only in that it throws an exception if this queue is empty.
        Specified by:
        remove in interface java.util.Queue<Event>
        Returns:
        the head of this queue
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if this queue is empty
